A complete record of all changes, including relevant context information
A single syntax to support the representation of all terminology assets, known and future
Status
Time

Module

asset must itself be identifiable
All Tinkar assets have STAMP values
assets in Tinkar must be identifiable (duplicate)
Published terminologies, with all existing features
Enumerated sets of concepts for specified purposes, a.k.a., value sets or refsets
Sets of associations or constraints composing an intensional definition of a value set
Sets of associations or constraints composing a logical definition of a concept
Sets of information about a concept as specified by a system; e.g., names (long, short, related, synonyms), codes, definitional properties, recommendations or constraints on use of units, change types
Sets of information about metadata elements, such as the language of a term or steward of a module
Associations among concepts, including relationships defined by member systems (LOINC system, MedRT mechanism of action, SNOMED CT finding site).
Associations among concepts, including classification & equivalence maps defined to harmonize and coordinate concepts common to different systems.
Sets of sets, supporting maps with multiple members. E.g., a set of Names may include a single preferred name and a contained set of synonyms. [Specific use cases should illustrate how our Semantics will probably have several layers]
Constraints on values
Logical compositional constraints on valid concepts, e.g., the SNOMED CT concept model
Syntactic compositional constraints on strings, e.g., MIME types, ISO languages, or UCUM units
[Magnitudes? Dates?]
Structural constraints, e.g., presence of exactly one name classified as “fully specified,” or names in specified languages
Rules that may govern modifications to other assets, e.g., incremental addition of effort estimates based on known problematic terms.
Constraints depend on (refer to) values to be constrained; values are not bound to constraints in ways that cannot be filtered out
Users can select contexts in which sets of constraints may or may not be applied
Modify component
An addition is a new version with a new chronology UUID.
Semantics may assert rules for additions to Modules, Paths, or other sets, e.g.,
A concept must have at least one name
A concept must have at least one parent
A Concept logical definition Semantic must have a definition status
A deletion is a new version of an existing chronology with status set to “inactive.”
Semantics may assert rules for deletions from Modules, Paths, or other sets, e.g.,
Children of deactivated concepts must be assigned a new parent
A change is a new version of an existing chronology with the new value(s), distinguishable by the time (and possibly other STAMP values).
A change may involve only a STAMP value; e.g., deactivation, or transfer of a concept to a new module or path.
Transfer involves a new version and a decision about whether to deactivate the old one.
Any modification must be followed by identification of dependent relationships.
A dependent relationship is a Semantic assertion that refers to a prior version of a changed component.
Semantics should specify approaches for handling kinds of changes.
Dependent relationships with rules may be handled automatically.
Dependent relationships without rules must be handled manually.
Multiple dependent relationships must be ordered to prevent redundant handling.
If dependent relationship [A] also depends on a second dependent relationship [B], then dependent relationship [B] should be addressed first.
Semantics are specific to module and path, so their rules are as well.
Rules may include or exclude modules or paths from their dependency graphs.
Rules will be applied at the time the change is recognized.
Terminology authoring activities will apply these rules at the time of authoring.
Export and publication activities may apply additional rules at the time of export or publication. These operations may be the equivalent of modifying the Path of a set of assets (i.e., creating a new set of versions specifying the new Path).
Import activities may apply import rules at the time of import.
The timeframe for rule disposition may be defined by the rule.
Publication is the copying of a set of Versions with a new Path.
Publication may invoke a specified set of rules or a higher level of stringency for previously applied rules.
Publication may or may not imply deactivation of the Versions in the prior path.
Export is the serialization of a data set (typically a published module or set of modules) into a file suitable for automated consumption by another terminology management system.
This serialization will conform to [specification]
Import is the automated consumption of an exported data set by a terminology management system.
[Context | Coordinate] management
A minimal set of STAMP values (time, module, and path) is required to determine the validity of any operation or Semantic.
Author may be used for this purpose, but is unlikely to be useful.
Status may be used to distinguish between “active-only” and “all” views.
A module dependency Semantic may be used to determine what modules depend on others – i.e., adopt assertions in the independent module. Such a Semantic must be acyclic.
[similar functionality for Paths?]
A user will be able to determine what modules a service supports, with their dependencies
Within the module, specific paths
Within the module, sets of Semantics defined by grouping Semantics, e.g., for specific use cases (such as quality measures) or specialties.
